project.teaser: Fungateria addresses a development gap in mycelium-based ELMs by developing a portfolio of ELMs that are composed of a synthetic co-cultivation consortium of a filamentous fungus and a bacterial strain. Sensing and adaptive growth of the fungal hyphae are exploited to develop...
project.objective: Fungateria addresses a development gap in mycelium-based ELMs by developing a portfolio of ELMs that are composed of a synthetic co-cultivation consortium of a filamentous fungus and a bacterial strain. Sensing and adaptive growth of the fungal hyphae are exploited to develop an autonomous bottom-up and scalable manufacturing technology called Growth Composing (GC) that enables an engineered morphogenesis of mycelium materials using robotically controlled spray nozzles that generate local air, gas or aerosol flows steering hyphal growth. In addition, bioprinting is used to deposit inocula of the engineered bacterial strain in specific patterns and at specific times throughout the production process. Various ELM products are developed, ranging from consumer goods to applications in the environmental and construction sector, which become active through environmental cues of light, temperature and chemical attractants. To this end, synthetic biology engineering will be implemented to use the bacterial strain as a chassis for sensor-containing genetic circuits that render advanced functionalities to the ELM throughout its life cycle, either through direct activity or by influencing growth and morphology of the fungal partner. ELM activity is verified with probes that reveal bio-electric signaling in the materials - providing additional dimensions of control, monitoring, functionality and exploitation as actively computing devices. When no longer needed or having reached the end of their productive life, kill switches are activated either by human-controlled environmental triggers or triggers of the system itself, thereby causing the ELM to fully and quickly degrade without causing any negative environmental impact. Throughout the Fungateria project, a societal dialogue will be established to continuously align research objectives with ethical and regulatory requirements.
project.title: Enlisting synthetic fungal-bacterial consortia to produce multi-cellular mycelium-based ELMs with computational capability
project.keywords: mycelium, bacteria, co-cultivation, synthetic microbial consortia, air-flow controlled production, genetic circuits, living computing devices

article.title: Combining fungi and bacteria into novel biomaterials

result.title: Contribution to the regulatory debate in RP1.
result.description: Report on the activities outcomes and planned follow up to assess and address the ELMs portfolio needs This includes contribution to the regulatory debate by engaging early on and continuously with regulatory bodies Any confidential information related to these activities will be included in the technical report

result.title: Community portal
result.description: Community portal is established and populated with preliminary resources The aim of the portal is to provide a broader insight into ELM development beyond the focus of the Fungateria project

result.title: A dictionary of the patterns of endogenous spiking of proteinoid ensembles
result.description: Report on the design and manufacturing of the experimental setup for recording electrical activity of living composites in a controlled environment, and, from the results, develop a dictionary of the patterns of endogenous spiking of proteinoid ensembles.

result.title: ELSA activities in RP2
result.description: Report on the activities, outcomes and planned follow up to address ethical, legal and social aspects (ELSA). These activities include engagement with strategic partners (including the public), and dissemination of best practices and guidelines when applicable with the ELMs field. Any confidential information related to these activities will be included in the technical report.

result.title: Portfolio of ELM designs as digital models
result.description: Portfolio of digital designs for ELM morphologies informed by data on qualitative andquantitative parameters such as anticipated biomass generation, distribution and type of functionalities, computational capabilities and morphological development.

result.title: Website and project logo
result.description: The project website will be operational by M2 and continuously updated thereafter across the duration of the project The domain wwwfungateriaeu will be procuredThe project website will be a first port of call for external access to information relating to the project The website will be a gateway to multimedia presentations open software hardware research papers and SoMe channels and contains the social media links

result.title: Mapping emerging ethical, social and environmental issues for EML technologies
result.description: Report on the mapping of emerging ethical, social and environmental issues for EML technologies with special attention to identified issues of concern that are overlappingwith SDGs such as “sustainable cities and communities” and “responsible and consumption and production”.

result.title: Contribution to the regulatory debate in RP2
result.description: Report on the activities, outcomes and planned follow up to assess and address the ELMs portfolio needs. This includes contribution to the regulatory debate by engaging early on and continuously with regulatory bodies. Any confidential information related to these activities will be included in the technical report.

result.title: Design and hardware implementation of initial digital twin prototype (DTP)
result.description: This deliverable reports on the design and hardware implementation of an initial Digital Twin Prototype (DTP) using and an accumulation of modelling methods (i.e., finite element methods, cellular automata, various neural networks) to mimic the production of ELMs and, most important, their electrical behavior.

result.title: Periodic Reporting for period 2 - Fungateria (Enlisting synthetic fungal-bacterial consortia to produce multi-cellular mycelium-based ELMs with computational capability)
result.teaser: Alongside rapid developments in the ELM field, there is a rapidly increasing interest in the research and development of mycelium materials, which are composed of the vegetative part of filamentous fungi. It can be envisaged that mycelium-based ELMs have a great potential...

category.title: Digital agenda
category.description: This tracker monitors Horizon Europe’s financial contribution to the development of digital technologies and the digitisation of the economy and society (known as ‘Digital transition’).

category.title: Clean air
category.description: This tracker monitors the Horizon Europe’s financial contribution to the clean air policy (National Emission Ceiling Directive) aiming to improve ambient air quality and tackle air pollution, to protect the environment and human health.

category.title: Artificial intelligence
category.description: This tracker monitors Horizon Europe’s financial contribution to the development and deployment of AI-based technologies and solutions. Projects that develop AI-tools as part of their research method are included

category.title: Climate action
category.description: This tracker monitors the Horizon Europe’s financial contribution to both mitigating climate change (e.g., contributions to the reduction of greenhouse gas emissions) and adapting to climate change by building resilience (e.g., regarding floods, droughts, spatial planning and better governance, adaptation to changing climate in value chains, etc.).

category.title: Biodiversity
category.description: This tracker monitors the Horizon Europe’s financial contribution to Europe’s biodiversity’s path to recovery including species protection, ecosystem conservation, and habitat rehabilitation, all essential for resilience in climate adaptation and addressing ecosystem services but also environmental crime and the health-environment connection.
